user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMemCmpCount:
```c
bool UtMemCmpCount(const void *Memory, uint32 Length)
{
    uint32       i;
    const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory;

    for (i = 0; i < Length; i++)
    {
        if (Byte_ptr[i] != (i & 0xFF))
        {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment only casts a void pointer to a uint8 pointer: const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory; Rule 21.17 specifically concerns use of <string.h> functions (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.). No such function is used here, so this fragment does not violate Rule 21.17. (Note: if Memory does not actually point to a buffer of at least Length bytes then later indexing Byte_ptr[i] could cause an out-of-bounds access, but that is a general bounds error and not a violation of Rule 21.17 as stated.)
